He who fears is not made perfect in love. We love him, because he first loved us.	Fear shrinks you. It makes you second-guess, hold back, and protect yourself. But love does the opposite. Love expands you. It gives you strength to show up when it's hard, to forgive when it hurts, and to move toward people instead of away from them.\n\nJohn writes that perfect love drives out fear. That's not a feelingit's a truth. When you are rooted in God's love, fear loses its grip. It doesn't disappear overnight. But it weakens every time you choose love over self-protection.\n\nDominion isn't control. It's not winning every argument or managing every outcome. Dominion is being steady enough in love that you can respond with grace, even when you're provoked.\n\nThink about the hardest relationships in your life. The ones where fear shows up as defensiveness, silence, or control. What would change if love led instead? Not weaknessbut the kind of strength that refuses to let fear write the narrative.\n\nToday, choose love. Not because it's easy. But because it's the truest expression of the life God has placed in you.	1 John was written to a community facing confusion about who Jesus was and how believers should live. John's repeated emphasis on love wasn't sentimentalit was corrective. Love was the mark of authentic faith. Fear-based religion was incomplete. The love of God, fully received, transforms how we treat others.	{"Name one relationship where fear has been louder than love.","Ask God to show you one step of love you can take today.","Memorize 1 John 4:18 and speak it over any area of fear."}	Take 2 minutes to reflect on today's message and apply it to one specific situation in your life.	How does today's truth speak to where you are right now?	\N	\N	/api/audio/spark-375-25699af9fd1109d6.mp3	{"sparkId": 375, "fileSize": 2160960, "publicUrl": "/api/audio/spark-375-25699af9fd1109d6.mp3", "contentHash": "25699af9fd1109d6", "generatedAt": "2026-01-09T02:15:49.518Z", "storagePath": "public/audio/spark-375-25699af9fd1109d6.mp3"}
421	Cast Your Cares	You weren't designed to carry the weight of worry. Today, release what's been pressing on your heart.	\N	\N	daily-devotional	120	2026-01-09 01:21:37.968998	/attached_assets/generated_images/day_14_faith_through_fire.png	video	\N	\N	1 Peter 5:7	scheduled	2026-01-16 05:00:00	2026-01-16	f	Jesus, I release my worries to You. Today's devotional invites you into a deeper understanding of what it means to live with dominion. Dominion is not about controlit's about trust. It's about resting in who God says you are while actively engaging in the world around you.\n\nThe Scripture for today reminds us that our strength comes from surrender, not striving. When we try to carry life on our own, we become exhausted and anxious. But when we learn to lean into God's grace, we find a power that sustains us.\n\nThis is the paradox of the Kingdom: we gain by giving, we find by seeking, and we live by dying to ourselves. Jesus modeled this for usnot through distant commands, but through His very life.\n\nAs you move through today, pay attention to where you're striving. Notice where anxiety is present. And in those moments, pause. Breathe. Invite God into the space. Dominion starts in the hidden places of the heart before it ever shows up in the visible areas of life.\n\nToday, take one step toward trust. Let go of one thing you've been gripping too tightly. And watch how freedom begins to grow.	The passages we explore in this series are rooted in both Old and New Testament themes of identity, authority, and purpose. The original audienceswhether ancient Israel or first-century believersfaced similar challenges to what we face today: pressure, fear, and the temptation to live from performance rather than position. These words still speak with power and relevance.	{"Identify one area where you've been striving and choose to trust instead.","Spend 5 minutes in stillness, inviting God's presence into your day.","Share today's truth with one person who might need encouragement."}	Take 2 minutes to reflect on today's message and apply it to one specific situation in your life. 411	The Secret Place	What happens in private shapes who you are in public. Your secret time with God matters more than you know.	\N	\N	daily-devotional	120	2026-01-09 01:21:37.887957	/attached_assets/generated_images/day_12_victory_triumph_mountain.png	video	\N	\N	Matthew 6:6	scheduled	2026-01-14 05:00:00	2026-01-14	f	Father, meet me in the secret place and transform me from the inside out.	Pray	The Secret Place	\N	Week 2: Prayer & Presence	early-career	But you, when you pray, enter into your inner room, and having shut your door, pray to your Father who is in secret; and your Father who sees in secret will reward you openly.	Today's devotional invites you into a deeper understanding of what it means to live with dominion. Dominion is not about controlit's about trust. It's about resting in who God says you are while actively engaging in the world around you.\n\nThe Scripture for today reminds us that our strength comes from surrender, not striving. When we try to carry life on our own, we become exhausted and anxious. But when we learn to lean into God's grace, we find a power that sustains us.\n\nThis is the paradox of the Kingdom: we gain by giving, we find by seeking, and we live by dying to ourselves. Jesus modeled this for usnot through distant commands, but through His very life.\n\nAs you move through today, pay attention to where you're striving. Notice where anxiety is present. And in those moments, pause. Breathe. Invite God into the space. Dominion starts in the hidden places of the heart before it ever shows up in the visible areas of life.\n\nToday, take one step toward trust. Let go of one thing you've been gripping too tightly. And watch how freedom begins to grow.	The passages we explore in this series are rooted in both Old and New Testament themes of identity, authority, and purpose. The original audienceswhether ancient Israel or first-century believersfaced similar challenges to what we face today: pressure, fear, and the temptation to live from performance rather than position. These words still speak with power and relevance.	{"Identify one area where you've been striving and choose to trust instead.","Spend 5 minutes in stillness, inviting God's presence into your day.","Share today's truth with one person who might need encouragement."}	Take 2 minutes to reflect on today's message and apply it to one specific situation in your life. But when we learn to lean into God's grace, we find a power that sustains us.\n\nThis is the paradox of the Kingdom: we gain by giving, we find by seeking, and we live by dying to ourselves. Jesus modeled this for usnot through distant commands, but through His very life.\n\nAs you move through today, pay attention to where you're striving. Notice where anxiety is present. And in those moments, pause. Breathe. Invite God into the space. Dominion starts in the hidden places of the heart before it ever shows up in the visible areas of life.\n\nToday, take one step toward trust. Let go of one thing you've been gripping too tightly. And watch how freedom begins to grow.	The passages we explore in this series are rooted in both Old and New Testament themes of identity, authority, and purpose. The original audienceswhether ancient Israel or first-century believersfaced similar challenges to what we face today: pressure, fear, and the temptation to live from performance rather than position. These words still speak with power and relevance.	{"Identify one area where you've been striving and choose to trust instead.","Spend 5 minutes in stillness, inviting God's presence into your day.","Share today's truth with one person who might need encouragement."}	Take 2 minutes to reflect on today's message and apply it to one specific situation in your life. Peace comes when you let go.	\N	\N	daily-devotional	120	2026-01-09 01:21:37.920624	/attached_assets/generated_images/day_13_collective_prayer_warfare.png	video	\N	\N	Philippians 4:6-7	scheduled	2026-01-15 05:00:00	2026-01-15	f	Lord, guard my heart and mind with Your supernatural peace.	Pray	Peace That Guards	\N	Week 3: Peace & Anxiety	universities	In nothing be anxious, but in everything, by prayer and petition with thanksgiving, let your requests be made known to God. And the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and your thoughts in Christ Jesus.	Today's devotional invites you into a deeper understanding of what it means to live with dominion. Dominion is not about controlit's about trust. It's about resting in who God says you are while actively engaging in the world around you.\n\nThe Scripture for today reminds us that our strength comes from surrender, not striving. When we try to carry life on our own, we become exhausted and anxious. But when we learn to lean into God's grace, we find a power that sustains us.\n\nThis is the paradox of the Kingdom: we gain by giving, we find by seeking, and we live by dying to ourselves. Jesus modeled this for usnot through distant commands, but through His very life.\n\nAs you move through today, pay attention to where you're striving. Notice where anxiety is present. And in those moments, pause. Breathe. Invite God into the space. Dominion starts in the hidden places of the heart before it ever shows up in the visible areas of life.\n\nToday, take one step toward trust. Let go of one thing you've been gripping too tightly. And watch how freedom begins to grow.	The passages we explore in this series are rooted in both Old and New Testament themes of identity, authority, and purpose. The original audienceswhether ancient Israel or first-century believersfaced similar challenges to what we face today: pressure, fear, and the temptation to live from performance rather than position. These words still speak with power and relevance.	{"Identify one area where you've been striving and choose to trust instead.","Spend 5 minutes in stillness, inviting God's presence into your day.","Share today's truth with one person who might need encouragement."}	Take 2 minutes to reflect on today's message and apply it to one specific situation in your life. 28	Dominion Through Love	Fear shrinks you; love strengthens you. Dominion is not controlit's being steady enough to choose love in real situations.	\N	\N	daily-devotional	120	2026-01-01 18:08:31.121091	/attached_assets/generated_images/day_5_peaceful_reflection_morning.png	video	\N	\N	1 John 4:18-19	scheduled	2026-01-07 05:00:00	2026-01-07	f	Father, fill me with Your love until fear loses its voice in my life.	Pray	Dominion Through Lov	9:16 thumbnail. Text: 'Love > Fear'. Background: bold contrasting colors, heart/light motif, modern minimal style.	Week 1: Identity & Belonging	\N	There is no fear in love; but perfect love casts out fear, because fear has punishment. He who fears is not made perfect in love. We love him, because he first loved us.	Fear shrinks you. It makes you second-guess, hold back, and protect yourself. But love does the opposite. Love expands you. It gives you strength to show up when it's hard, to forgive when it hurts, and to move toward people instead of away from them.\n\nJohn writes that perfect love drives out fear. That's not a feelingit's a truth. When you are rooted in God's love, fear loses its grip. It doesn't disappear overnight. But it weakens every time you choose love over self-protection.\n\nDominion isn't control. It's not winning every argument or managing every outcome. Dominion is being steady enough in love that you can respond with grace, even when you're provoked.\n\nThink about the hardest relationships in your life. The ones where fear shows up as defensiveness, silence, or control. What would change if love led instead? Not weaknessbut the kind of strength that refuses to let fear write the narrative.\n\nToday, choose love. Not because it's easy. But because it's the truest expression of the life God has placed in you.	1 John was written to a community facing confusion about who Jesus was and how believers should live. John's repeated emphasis on love wasn't sentimentalit was corrective. Love was the mark of authentic faith. Fear-based religion was incomplete. The love of God, fully received, transforms how we treat others.	{"Name one relationship where fear has been louder than love.","Ask God to show you one step of love you can take today.","Memorize 1 John 4:18 and speak it over any area of fear."}	Take 2 minutes to reflect on today's message and apply it to one specific situation in your life.	How does today's truth speak to where you are right now?	You notice how fear has been driving youoverthinking, people-pleasing, controlling outcomes. It's exhausting. Then you read: "Perfect love casts out fear," and it feels like a door opening.	Fear shrinks you. Love strengthens you. 1 John 4 says there's no fear in loveperfect love drives it out. Why? Because fear is always talking punishment: "What if I fail? What if they leave?"\nBut love tells a better story: "You are held."\nToday, don't fight fear with willpowerreplace fear with love. Receive God's love first, then move from security. You don't have to be ruled by fear when you're rooted in love.	/api/audio/spark-28-25699af9fd1109d6.mp3	{"sparkId": 28, "fileSize": 2172000, "publicUrl": "/api/audio/spark-28-25699af9fd1109d6.mp3", "contentHash": "25699af9fd1109d6", "generatedAt": "2026-01-09T02:05:50.335Z", "storagePath": "public/audio/spark-28-25699af9fd1109d6.mp3"}

Today's devotional invites you into a deeper understanding of what it means to live with dominion. Dominion is not about controlit's about trust. It's about resting in who God says you are while actively engaging in the world around you.\n\nThe Scripture for today reminds us that our strength comes from surrender, not striving. When we try to carry life on our own, we become exhausted and anxious. But when we learn to lean into God's grace, we find a power that sustains us.\n\nThis is the paradox of the Kingdom: we gain by giving, we find by seeking, and we live by dying to ourselves. Jesus modeled this for usnot through distant commands, but through His very life.\n\nAs you move through today, pay attention to where you're striving. Notice where anxiety is present. And in those moments, pause. Breathe. Invite God into the space. Dominion starts in the hidden places of the heart before it ever shows up in the visible areas of life.\n\nToday, take one step toward trust. Let go of one thing you've been gripping too tightly. And watch how freedom begins to grow.	The passages we explore in this series are rooted in both Old and New Testament themes of identity, authority, and purpose. The original audienceswhether ancient Israel or first-century believersfaced similar challenges to what we face today: pressure, fear, and the temptation to live from performance rather than position. These words still speak with power and relevance.	{"Identify one area where you've been striving and choose to trust instead.","Spend 5 minutes in stillness, inviting God's presence into your day.","Share today's truth with one person who might need encouragement."}	Take 2 minutes to reflect on today's message and apply it to one specific situation in your life. But when we learn to lean into God's grace, we find a power that sustains us.\n\nThis is the paradox of the Kingdom: we gain by giving, we find by seeking, and we live by dying to ourselves. Jesus modeled this for usnot through distant commands, but through His very life.\n\nAs you move through today, pay attention to where you're striving. Notice where anxiety is present. And in those moments, pause. Breathe. Invite God into the space. Dominion starts in the hidden places of the heart before it ever shows up in the visible areas of life.\n\nToday, take one step toward trust. Let go of one thing you've been gripping too tightly. And watch how freedom begins to grow.	The passages we explore in this series are rooted in both Old and New Testament themes of identity, authority, and purpose. The original audienceswhether ancient Israel or first-century believersfaced similar challenges to what we face today: pressure, fear, and the temptation to live from performance rather than position. These words still speak with power and relevance.	{"Identify one area where you've been striving and choose to trust instead.","Spend 5 minutes in stillness, inviting God's presence into your day.","Share today's truth with one person who might need encouragement."}	Take 2 minutes to reflect on today's message and apply it to one specific situation in your life. 362	Seated, Not Shaken	Dominion is perspective before it is performance. When life feels loud, remember you're not beneath fearyou're invited into a higher view. Calm begins when you stop fighting from the ground.	\N	\N	daily-devotional	120	2026-01-09 01:21:37.576859	/attached_assets/generated_images/day_2_confident_identity_sunrise.png	video	\N	\N	Ephesians 2:4-6	scheduled	2026-01-04 05:00:00	2026-01-04	f	Jesus, lift my perspective and settle my heart in Your victory today.	Pray	Seated, Not Shaken	\N	Week 1: Identity & Belonging	builders	But God, being rich in mercy, for his great love with which he loved us, even when we were dead through our trespasses, made us alive together with Christby grace you have been savedand raised us up with him, and made us to sit with him in the heavenly places in Christ Jesus.	Dominion is perspective before it is performance. When life feels loudwhen the pressure builds and uncertainty swirlsyour first instinct may be to react, to fix, to fight. But God invites you into something different: a seat above the noise.\n\nPaul describes this seat in Ephesians 2. You have been raised with Christ and seated with Him in heavenly places. That's not just poetic language. It's your position. Before you engage the challenges of today, remember where you're seated. You're not beneath the chaosyou're above it, with Him.\n\nThis doesn't mean you ignore reality. It means you engage from a different posture. When fear tries to push you into panic, you can pause and remember: this is not my first battle, and God has already won the war. That truth changes how you show up.\n\nThe enemy wants you to live from reactivity. But dominion is about response, not reaction. Respond from rest. Respond from trust. Respond from the seat God has given younot because you're passive, but because you're positioned.\n\nToday, don't let circumstances define your capacity. Let your position define your peace.	Ephesians was written to a church navigating pressure from both Roman culture and internal conflict. Paul's language of being 'seated with Christ' reminded them that their identity was not determined by external circumstances but by their union with Jesus. The 'heavenly places' are not a distant futurethey describe present spiritual reality and authority.	{"When anxiety rises, pause and declare: 'I am seated, not shaken.'","Before reacting to a situation, ask: 'What would it look like to respond from rest?'","Write Ephesians 2:6 somewhere you'll see it today."}	Take 2 minutes to reflect on today's message and apply it to one specific situation in your life.	How does today's truth speak to where you are right now?	\N	\N	/api/audio/spark-362-79c724c8b4b1cc8d.mp3	{"sparkId": 362, "fileSize": 2411040, "publicUrl": "/api/audio/spark-362-79c724c8b4b1cc8d.mp3", "contentHash": "79c724c8b4b1cc8d", "generatedAt": "2026-01-09T02:12:31.158Z", "storagePath": "public/audio/spark-362-79c724c8b4b1cc8d.mp3"}
26	Chosen for Influence	You were made to bring light, not just survive the day. Pray	Chosen for Influence	9:16 thumbnail. Text: 'Chosen'. Background: bright focal light behind a silhouette walking forward; hopeful, bold, minimal.	Week 1: Identity & Belonging	\N	But you are a chosen race, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a people for God's own possession, that you may proclaim the excellence of him who called you out of darkness into his marvelous light.	You are not an afterthought. Before you walked into this day, God had already chosen younot just for salvation, but for influence. You are called to be a royal priesthood, a people set apart. That phrase is not about exclusion; it's about purpose.\n\nPeter's words to early believers still echo today: you are chosen. You are called. You are meant to declare His praisesnot from a stage, but from your life. Influence doesn't always look like visibility. Sometimes it looks like consistency. Sometimes it's the person who shows up steady when everyone else is spiraling.\n\nDominion through influence is not about control. It's about presence. When you walk into a room grounded in who God says you are, the atmosphere shifts. You don't have to demand attention. You can simply carry light.\n\nInfluence grows when you stop trying to prove yourself and start living from your identity. You are not auditioning for acceptance. You've already been chosen. Now, live like it.\n\nToday, carry the confidence of someone who belongs to Godand watch how your presence begins to change the space around you.	Peter wrote to scattered believers who felt like outsiders in their own culture. His words reframed their marginalization: they weren't rejectedthey were chosen. The language of 'royal priesthood' echoes Exodus 19, where Israel was called to mediate God's presence to the world. Now, that calling extends to all who follow Jesus.	{"Identify one space today where you can carry lightwork, school, home.","Replace any 'I have to prove myself' thoughts with 'I have already been chosen.'","Ask God: 'How do You want to use my presence today?'"}	Take 2 minutes to reflect on today's message and apply it to one specific situation in your life.	How does today's truth speak to where you are right now?	You're in a room where you feel smallnew people, big personalities, lots of opinions. You start shrinking back. Then you remember: you're not invisible. You're chosen to carry light.	You were made for more than survivalyou were chosen for influence. 1 Peter 2:9 says you're chosen, royal, and God's ownso you can proclaim His excellence.\nInfluence isn't about being loud. It's about being anchored. When you know who you are, you stop chasing validation and start carrying light.\nToday, ask: "Where can I bring hope?" Your kindness, courage, and consistency can be someone else's reminder that God is real.	/api/audio/spark-26-fdda188c0db6005c.mp3	{"sparkId": 26, "fileSize": 2254080, "publicUrl": "/api/audio/spark-26-fdda188c0db6005c.mp3", "contentHash": "fdda188c0db6005c", "generatedAt": "2026-01-09T01:42:00.756Z", "storagePath": "public/audio/spark-26-fdda188c0db6005c.mp3"}

370	Testimony: From Pressure to Peace	This is a real story of calm arriving in the middle of pressure. If you've been carrying stress, let this remind you that peace is possible.	\N	\N	testimony	120	2026-01-09 01:21:37.642143	/attached_assets/generated_images/day_4_hands_reaching_light.png	video	\N	\N	John 14:27	scheduled	2026-01-06 05:00:00	2026-01-06	f	Jesus, meet me in my pressure and give me peace that holds.	Pray	Testimony	\N	Week 1: Identity & Belonging	universities	Peace I leave with you. My peace I give to you; not as the world gives, I give to you. Don't let your heart be troubled, neither let it be fearful.	There's a moment when pressure stops feeling temporary and starts feeling permanent. It builds. It presses. And without warning, it becomes your normal.\n\nThis is the story of someone who lived therejuggling expectations, managing anxiety, and wondering when the weight would lift. For months, they carried it silently, convinced that rest was a luxury and peace was for other people.\n\nBut then something shifted. Not the circumstances. The posture. A simple prayer began to change everything: 'Lord, I can't carry this. I need You to.' It wasn't dramatic. It was desperate. And in that desperation, peace came.\n\nNot the absence of pressurebut a presence in the middle of it. Peace didn't remove the deadline. It gave the strength to face it. Peace didn't change the relationship. It gave the clarity to navigate it.\n\nThis is what Jesus meant when He said, 'My peace I give to younot as the world gives.' It's not circumstantial. It's supernatural.\n\nIf you're in the middle of pressure today, take a moment. Stop striving. Let go of the illusion of control. And invite peacenot as an escape, but as an anchor.	John 14 records Jesus speaking to His disciples just before His crucifixion. He knew they would face intense pressure, confusion, and fear. His promise of peace was both a present gift and a future assurance: the Holy Spirit would sustain them. The same Spirit offers you peace today.	{"Identify where you've been carrying pressure that's not yours to carry.","Speak this out loud: 'Lord, I release what I cannot control.'","Pause three times today to breathe deeply and invite God's peace."}	Take 2 minutes to reflect on today's message and apply it to one specific situation in your life. 380	Living Light in Darkness	The world around you is looking for something real. Your life can be that lightnot by being perfect, but by being present.	\N	\N	daily-devotional	120	2026-01-09 01:21:37.706779	/attached_assets/generated_images/day_6_unity_circle_together.png	video	\N	\N	Matthew 5:14-16	scheduled	2026-01-08 05:00:00	2026-01-08	f	Lord, help me shine Your light wherever darkness needs to be pierced.	Pray	Living Light in Dark	\N	Week 1: Identity & Belonging	universities	You are the light of the world. A city located on a hill can't be hidden. Neither do you light a lamp and put it under a measuring basket, but on a stand; and it shines to all who are in the house. Even so, let your light shine before men, that they may see your good works and glorify your Father who is in heaven.	Today's devotional invites you into a deeper understanding of what it means to live with dominion. Dominion is not about controlit's about trust. It's about resting in who God says you are while actively engaging in the world around you.\n\nThe Scripture for today reminds us that our strength comes from surrender, not striving. When we try to carry life on our own, we become exhausted and anxious. But when we learn to lean into God's grace, we find a power that sustains us.\n\nThis is the paradox of the Kingdom: we gain by giving, we find by seeking, and we live by dying to ourselves. Jesus modeled this for usnot through distant commands, but through His very life.\n\nAs you move through today, pay attention to where you're striving. Notice where anxiety is present. And in those moments, pause. Breathe. Invite God into the space. Dominion starts in the hidden places of the heart before it ever shows up in the visible areas of life.\n\nToday, take one step toward trust. Let go of one thing you've been gripping too tightly. And watch how freedom begins to grow.	The passages we explore in this series are rooted in both Old and New Testament themes of identity, authority, and purpose. It's about resting in who God says you are while actively engaging in the world around you.\n\nThe Scripture for today reminds us that our strength comes from surrender, not striving. When we try to carry life on our own, we become exhausted and anxious. But when we learn to lean into God's grace, we find a power that sustains us.\n\nThis is the paradox of the Kingdom: we gain by giving, we find by seeking, and we live by dying to ourselves. Jesus modeled this for usnot through distant commands, but through His very life.\n\nAs you move through today, pay attention to where you're striving. Notice where anxiety is present. And in those moments, pause. Breathe. Invite God into the space. Dominion starts in the hidden places of the heart before it ever shows up in the visible areas of life.\n\nToday, take one step toward trust. Let go of one thing you've been gripping too tightly. And watch how freedom begins to grow.	The passages we explore in this series are rooted in both Old and New Testament themes of identity, authority, and purpose. The original audienceswhether ancient Israel or first-century believersfaced similar challenges to what we face today: pressure, fear, and the temptation to live from performance rather than position. These words still speak with power and relevance.	{"Identify one area where you've been striving and choose to trust instead.","Spend 5 minutes in stillness, inviting God's presence into your day.","Share today's truth with one person who might need encouragement."}	Take 2 minutes to reflect on today's message and apply it to one specific situation in your life. -- Data for Name: vision_exports; Type: TABLE DATA; Schema: public; Owner: -
--

COPY public.vision_exports (id, session_id, export_type, url, created_at) FROM stdin;
\.


--
-- Data for Name: vision_goals; Type: TABLE DATA; Schema: public; Owner: -
--

\.

COPY public.volunteer_signups (id, name, email, phone, areas, message, user_id, created_at, segment) FROM stdin;

2	Test Volunteer	volunteer-test@example.com	555-1234	{Events,Tech}	\N	\N	2026-01-04 23:27:46.237274	\N
